Answer: Yes, it certainly sounds like a good idea: develop a safe cigarette / a cancer-free cigarette / whatever.There‚Äôs one small problem though: the smoke. Smoke is toxic and cancerous whatever it comes from, however it is created, whatever you do to filter it. If there‚Äôs any smoke left it is inherently harmful because it‚Äôs smoke.So what we would need to do, to make safe smoke, is:Yes, it certainly sounds like a good idea: develop a safe cigarette / a cancer-free cigarette / whatever.There‚Äôs one small problem though: the smoke. Smoke is toxic and cancerous whatever it comes from, however it is created, whatever you do to filter it. If there‚Äôs any smoke left it is inherently harmful because it‚Äôs smoke.So what we would need to do, to make safe smoke, is:OK so now we have no particulate matter and no gases. Job done. There‚Äôs a problem though: there‚Äôs almost nothing left - we removed it all. No smoke >> no harm >> but no nothing.Not strictly true though: we‚Äôll be left with about 5% of the original aerosol that was heated water vapour and liquids-based aerosols. These were sucked out of the tobacco column as it heated up, before the ignition reached it. These vapour-based products are not all that harmful compared to the solids-based aerosols (smoke particles) and exhaust gases.HnBJob done.Simple HnB products remove about 90% of the toxic exposures delivered by cigarettes, so that‚Äôs pretty good. Complex and more expensive HnB can do a slightly better job. It‚Äôs a big advance over a cigarette.Smoke#ITSS ‚ÄîLose the smoke, fix the problem.
